oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Highway 101 Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Highway 101 (performance group) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Highway 101; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Biff Collie tells the Highway 101 group about the radio spots -- (00:57) Scott "Cactus" Moser and Curtis Stone introduce themselves as part of Music City Album Review radio spot -- (01:08) Collie and Moser discuss tweaking his radio spot -- (01:28) Moser and Stone introduce themselves as part of Music City Album Review radio spot -- (01:38) Paint the Town album review messed up by Stone and Moser and Stone introduce themselves as part of Music City Album Review radio spot -- (02:03) Moser miss speaks -- (02:06) Moser radio spot invitation to the Music City Album Review -- (02:14) Stone and Moser joke about the "Biffer" and introduce album in thirty minute radio spot -- (02:35) Moser and Stone introduce album in hour radio spot -- (02:53) Moser misspeaks -- (03:00) Moser and Stone Music City Album review hour radio spot -- (03:10) Stone introduce themselves back from midway break for radio spot -- (03:18) Moser and Stone introduce album in Music City Album Review radio spot -- (03:38) Stone and Moser Music City Album Review radio spot -- (3:47) Stone and Moser thank the listeners in radio spot -- (03:58) Moser and Stone Music City Album review ninety minute radio spot -- (04:05) Moser asking if viewers want a big finish radio spot -- (04:11) Stone and Moser say they enjoy hosting in radio spot -- (04:27) Moser messes up first attempt so Moser and Stone present goodbye radio spot -- (04:47) Collie tells Moser and Stone how to be the host -- (05:11) "I Can't Love You Baby" is discussed by Moser regarding his drum intro and Stone discusses his solo -- (06:05) Stone tells about the first time the group got together in Denver, Colorado and Paulette Carlson joining through Chuck Morris -- (07:30) Moser and Stone talk about Chuck Morris' importance and success -- (09:09) Stone talks about the first time he talked to Carlson, sending her tapes to Minnesota, and meeting Moser in a club -- (10:35) "If Love Had a Heart" is discussed by Stone as the debate with Matraca Berg to the identity of the song -- (11:32) Collie Moser and Stone joke about who is Moser and Moser describes how he got the his love for drums through a childhood desire to hit -- (13:30) Moser tells that he got the same Cactus when he was playing in Rock bands while being from the country -- (14:20) Collie, Moser and Stone joke about being able to write and work in music -- (15:04) "While You Slept Last Night" is discussed by Moser and Stone and they address their friendship with song-write Pam Tillis -- (16:07) Moser talks about the decision making process behind every song to reach the album -- (16:40) Moser and Stone talks about "This Side of Goodbye" how there were mistakes on writing credits -- (17:30) Moser talks about being a writer at Warner Brothers and the relaxed feeling of work -- (18:22) Collie and Stone discuss Stone's past about Collie's familiarity of his family -- (18:52) Stone discusses about living in north Hollywood with his father Cliffie Stone and his father discovering Tennessee Ernie Ford -- (20:30) Stone jokes about getting upset at his father -- (21:14) Stone talks about Central Songs and the connections to music publishing -- (22:25) Stone talks about going to a Christmas show with Cash (Johnny) and Cash getting hit on the head -- (23:01) Collie talks about the first time he talked to Cliffie Stone while he was with Hank Williams and Stone talks about hearing Collie's name at home -- (24:40) Stone and Moser talk about "Walkin', Talkin', Cryin', Barely Beatin' Broken Heart" and working with a humorous Roger Miller on the music video -- (25:46) Moser talks about finding older songs from publishers noticing their underlying energy -- (27:03) "I'll Paint the Town" is discussed by Stone as Mark Brown coming to him and Stone being unsure if it was a country song and Moser talks about working with Gretchen Peters and the music community in whole -- (29:03) Collie and Moser discuss being both a writer and an artist and being able to step outside of emotional ties to songs -- (30:05) Stone talks about their numerous recordings in Nashville beyond their album -- (30:37) Collie and Stone talk about the dramatic change for the band from four years prior -- (31:57) Stone talks about his age and the variety of projects he had been in before success -- (32:45) Collie recalls a quote from Arnold about hit records -- (33:34) Stone calls "Rough and Tuble Heart" his favorite off the album and Stone, Moser and Collie reflect on Tillis -- (35:29) Collie addresses Larry Gatlin and Stone and Moser reflect on the intimidation of demoing songs -- (37:03) "Midnight Angel" and Carlson are reflected on as having jaded purity to her -- (40:06) Collie, Moser and Stone reflect on being a unit and removing personal attachments to success and Alabama's original spark -- (41:31) Stone talks about the change of styling when recording "Who's Lonely Now" and his hesitation while Moser discusses his instant love with the track -- (43:02) Collie, Stone and Moser talk about guitarist Jack Daniels, his first shows with Freddy Heart and visiting the Grand Ole Opry -- (44:27) Moser reflects on how people react to his and Daniel's names and Daniel's versatility -- (46:10) Moser reflects on getting James Taylor's "Sweet Baby James" to perform live -- (48:10) Stone and Moser reflect on the technical components on deciding to leaving the track natural -- (48:50) Stone and Moser discuss the breakup of Highway 101; or more correctly, the rumor that Highway 101 was breaking up -- (52:31) Collie talks about how Loretta Lynn about how she perceived the press -- (53:20) Moser, Stone and Collie say goodbye and Stone says he will tell his father hello for Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Highway 101 (Musical group); Collie, Biff;
